content.description:
Good steep climb. Its starts in a blocky section to the let of the area and climbs the left side of a roof. It finishes with a hero dyne.



The very left side of The Wave

7 bolts

Climbs the arete, the bottom two bolts are probably the most challenging sections of climbing on this climb, the grade may be a little soft after the half way point but at least one of the bolts is a bit farther from the previous one to keep things spicy.

This route is right on the eastern arete on this crag, right beside the small squeeze crack (Let's Get Ready to Rumble, 5.9). There are a couple other climbs further on the eastern face but they aren't the cream of the crop here.
5 bolts, chain anchor.

The guidebook states that this is voted the steepest and most fun per move climb at Skaha. Feels like one big boulder problem. It is acrobatic, sustained, and fully earns its rating.

The western-most sport climb on The Wave. You will see this one first if you are approaching from Another Buttress. It is a steep cave-like bay. Watch out for poison ivy around the base, but I guess that goes for all climbing at Skaha.
7 bolts, chain anchors.

A retrobolted sport chimney. Dirty, and just not the same quality as some of the other climbs in this area (UPDATE: cleaned up a lot since original posting). Worth a quick climb if you still need a warm up.

It's the obvious line of bolts up the edge of a chimney. Just to the left of I'm Not Too Sure.
5 bolts. Use the chain anchors to the right and not the ones for Straight into the Arms of Venus de Milo (5.11d) on the left.

climbs.name: Life Crisis
climbs.fa: Prep, Peter Arbic; FA, Ben MacCaughly, 2009

content.description:
A handful of intro-climbing moves to a nasty boulder problem that finishes on a bucket. 

Turns out that bucket is a sloper, but it's good and if you hit it the route is over. Merge with "October Crisis" for a few bolts of moderately pumpy climbing. 

Definitely do not skip the first bolt and do consider stick-clipping it (or the second) - the move off the deck isn't exactly hard, but it is very dropable. Skip bolt 3 once the draws are on. 



Find the "Reach for the Rabbit" overhanging crack/corner. This line is immediately right of this and loosely goes up the arete/left facing corner. Trend right once the angle eases off (there are a couple of rogue bolts out left up high).

8 bolts, fixed anchor with biners

Follow the bolt line from the left edge of the shelf up the right facing, overhanging corner. Approximately 1 meter of nice holds gets you to pulling very hard on underclings, with the crux coming at the gap in the underclings. 

After you hit the block on the corner, it's over. Make sure your gate faces to the right on your last bolt to prevent the biner from nosing in.



Middle/right of the wall, look for a right facing corner with bolts, just above the left end of the shelf/ramp. 

6 bolts, chains (no biners)

This is a VERY popular climb, with good reason. It is all overhung and traverses left up to an increasingly crimpy finish.

In the center of the eastern white Wave section, maybe 50 feet left of the chimney. The only route with fixed draws.
Fixed draws with two for anchors. There may be a bolt or two without fixed draws.

Boulder off the deck (consider stick clipping the second bolt) on good holds. Finish the boulder by slamming a turbo-bucket and then pull over the roof into a rest. 

Continue up the left leaning corner (face climbing) until the bolts hook back to the right. Disproportionate pump for how big the holds are and how not steep it is - race the pump to the chains!



Locate "Reach for the Rabbit" the distinct overhanging crack/left facing corner. Immediately to the right is "Life Crisis" which is the direct start to "October Crisis". One more bolt line to the right is this line which traverses in to merge with "Life Crisis" at the 4th bolt. 

7 bolts, fixed anchor with biners

Head up the obvious left facing dihedral in the center of the wave for about 20 ft of smeary crack climbing until the business starts.  Try to find a good stemming rest, manage a difficult clip, and then head into the roof.  Work through a couple bouldery moves and stab for the “rabbit” on the left. 



Climbs the obvious left facing dihedral in the center of the wave. 

Bolts

The crux is at the anchor involving some committing moves. Hard move at the end for the grade.

Right most line with 4 bolts.
4 bolts and bolted anchor.

climbs.name: Straight into the Arms of Venus de Milo

content.description:
Slightly overhung, starts off tweaky and delicate. Short legs help on the cruxy first bit to get into the increasingly burly and sustained climbing above. Seems harder than its neighbour, the popular 5.12a Not Fade Away.

Immediately to the left of the chimney.
6 bolts, chain anchors

An easy mini-boulder to a rest and then an actual boulder over the lip. Typical of the wall, surprisingly pumpy for its brevity with generally good holds. 



This route is right of the obvious "Reach for the Rabbit" overhanging crack/corner. Walk uphill (3 first bolts right) until you see a loosely defined, right leaning, left-facing corner feature, with two perma-draws at the bulge (may only see one from below), this is your line!

5 bolts, 2 perma's, fixed anchor with biners.

There is a lot of climbing packed into this short route. Considered a crag classic...at least by Marc Bourdon. Walk up a left leaning ramp and clip 2 bolts using super-buckets. After this, the climb steps up!

Move along a flake and solve a mini-boulder using a two-finger mono. The main boulder comes at the mid-height lip - a powerful span and blind feet. After the boulder there is still a pretty serious red-point crux clearing the next lip!



Towards the right end of the wave, this is the second bolt-line fully left of the chimney. About even with the left (west) edge of the peanut gallery boulder.

7 bolts, fixed anchor with biners

The Wave is a south-facing crag and mostly overhanging. It gets good shade in the mornings and has a nice view across to Red Tail and Skaha Lake. It contains some high quality overhung 5.12 sport climbs with a couple 5.11 climbs thrown in the mix. The highest-travelled routes can be popular during busy days, but you'll find something available if you climb 5.11/5.12.
